questions.question: What is the generalized quantifier?
questions.explanation: Quantifier: most, few, exactly n, etc. Example: 'Most students passed'. Logic: extends first-order. Complexity: higher-order. Application: natural language. Importance: expressivity extension.

questions.question: What is branching quantification?
questions.explanation: Notation: quantifiers not linearly ordered. Meaning: some independent of others. Example: Henkin quantifiers. Power: expresses non-first-order properties. Application: game theory, AI. Importance: expressivity extension.

questions.question: What is infinitary logic?
questions.explanation: Logic: L?,? allows infinite operators. Power: stronger than first-order. Limitation: not compact. Application: advanced mathematics. Importance: theory. Restriction: loses properties.

questions.question: What is modality with quantifiers?
questions.explanation: Logic: x P(x) vs x P(x) different. Interaction: complex. Application: specification. Importance: expressivity. Challenge: semantics intricate.

questions.question: What is the L�wenheim-Skolem theorem?
questions.explanation: Theorem: first-order theory with infinite model has countable model. Implication: can't axiomatize uncountability. Application: model theory. Importance: foundational. Developer: L�wenheim, Skolem.

questions.question: What is Craig interpolation?
questions.explanation: Theorem: if f  ?, there interpolant ?. Meaning: f  ?  ? and ? uses common symbols. Application: proof analysis. Importance: theoretical result. Developer: William Craig.

questions.question: What is Beth definability?
questions.explanation: Theorem: implicit definition makes explicit definition. Implication: eliminability. Application: definition theory. Importance: theoretical. Developer: Evert Beth.

questions.question: What is the Herbrand theorem?
questions.explanation: Theorem: formula satisfiable iff finite Herbrand model. Purpose: reduce to ground instances. Application: automated reasoning. Importance: SAT solver foundation. Developer: Jacques Herbrand.

questions.question: What is unification?
questions.explanation: Problem: given terms t,s find s s.t. s(t)=s(s). Algorithm: Robinson's algorithm. Application: logic programming, resolution. Importance: core algorithm. Complexity: linear time.

questions.question: What is resolution with quantifiers?
questions.explanation: Rule: from CA and BD infer CD where s(A)=s(B). Unification: essential. Soundness: valid inference. Completeness: for unsatisfiability. Application: automated theorem proving. Importance: fundamental.
